children.name: really
children.definition: when you really feel sth,reallywant sth etc, and you are not just pretending to feel it: thật sự
examples: Do you think she’s really sorry?
Do you really want to come with us? It’ll be very boring for you.
I don’t think she really believes she can win.

children.name: real
children.definition: use this to describe feelings, attitudes and beliefs that someone really feels and is not just pretending to feel : thật sự
examples: She was clearly in real pain.
He didn’t show any real regret for the suffering he had caused.
Real commitment is needed from everyone on the team if we’re going to make this project work.

children.name: sincere
children.definition: if you are sincere, or have sincere feelings, you really feel or believe sth and are not just pretending: chân thành, thành thật
examples: It is my sincere belief that if we work together we can achieve peace in this country.
sincere in
They seemed to be sincere in their concern for the children’s welfare.
sincere thanks/ apologiesformal
I would like to express my sincere thanks to all those who helped us.
sincerely[adv]
I believe they sincerely want to find a peaceful solution to the dispute.

children.name: genuine
children.definition: genuine feelings are real and not pretended - use this especially when you are surprised that sb has these feelings: thật lòng
examples: I’m not sure if her sympathy was really genuine.
For the first time on the trip, I saw genuine fear in his eyes
genuinely[adv] một cách thật lòng
Fred seemed genuinely interested in our work.

children.name: heartfelt
children.definition: very real and strongly felt: thật lòng
examples: She expressed her heartfelt thanks to all those who had helped and supported her.
Please accept our heartfelt sympathy on your sad loss.
formalPlease accept my heartfeltapologies/thanks.

children.name: from the heart
children.definition: if you say or mean sth from the heart, you really mean it and feel it very strongly: tận đáy lòng
examples: He stood up and spoke simply but from the heart.
straight from the heart
I’m speaking straight from the heart when I say that I believe Marguerite deserves to be chairman.
from the bottom of sb’s heart
I want to thank you from the bottom of my heart.
When I said I loved you, Imeantit from the bottom of my heart.

children.name: truly
children.definition: if you truly believe, want, or feel sth, you believe, want, or feel it very strongly and are not just pretending: thực sự
examples: I truly believe he is innocent.
She seems truly sorry for what she did.
I truly am impressed with your work.
Truly I could not have done this without you.
He trulybelieveshe can cure himself by willpower alone.

children.name: true
children.definition: a feeling that is real and strongly felt, not just pretended: thực sự
examples: At last he had found true happiness.
As far as Gabby was concerned this was true love.

children.name: sb who does not cheat, steal, break the law etc
can trust
children.definition: if you can trust sb, you are sure that they are honest and that you can depend on them: có thể tin cậy
examples: Beth’s an honest hardworking girl who I know I can trust.
can trust sb to do sth
I knew I could trust Neil to look after the money.

children.name: honest
children.definition: sb who is honest does not lie, steal or cheat, and can be trusted: ngay thật
examples: He’s one of the few honest politicians we have left.
As the job involves handling large amounts of money, it’s essential that our workers are honest.
scrupulously honest: [very careful to always be completely honest]
She was scrupulously honest in all her business dealings.
honestly[adv] [B2]
I’m not convinced that the salesman dealt with us honestly.

children.name: reputable
children.definition: known to be honest, especially in your business activities: có uy tín
examples: She had her antique vases valued by a reputable dealer.
Before you buy a used car it’s best to go to a reputable garage.
How do we know that all the firms involved in this deal are reputable?

children.name: above suspicion
children.definition: known to be very honest - use this especially about sb who is in a position in which it is important to be trusted: không ai còn nghi ngờ
examples: People who look after other people’s money should be above suspicion.
During the investigation no one will be considered above suspicion.

children.name: honest
children.definition: sb who is honest says what they really think or what is really happening, and does not try to hide the truth or deceive people: thật thà
examples: You can always rely on Stewart to be honest.
honest about
I don’t think she’s being completely honest about what she knows.
be honest with sb
All we are asking is that management be honest with us, even if the situation is difficult.
honest answer/ reply etc
Tell me where you were - and I want an honest answer.
honestly[adv] [B2] một cách thành thật
Tell me honestly, are you in love with her?

children.name: sincere
children.definition: showing your true feelings and what you really believe: thành thật
examples: She said she would love to come, but I wasn’t sure if she was being sincere.
My client extends his sincere apologies to anyone who may have been hurt by his actions.

children.name: truthful
children.definition: sb who is truthful does not lie: trung thực, thật thà
examples: As a child she was obedient and truthful.
Not everyone believes the government is being truthful.
truthful about
He has clearly not been truthful about the nature of their relationship.
be truthful with sb
I hope we can be truthful with each other.
Are you being quite truthfulwithme?
truthful account/story/answer etc
It is unlikely that a truthful account of conditions in the prison will ever be seen.
truthfully[adv] một cách trung thực
Jackson claims he answered the questions truthfully.

children.name: open
children.definition: honest, friendly, and happy to tell other people the truth, especially about things that other people might be embarrassed to talk about: cởi mở, thật lòng
examples: Diana’s very easy to talk to because she’s so open.
He’s a nice looking young man with an open, honest smile.
I wish you'd be more openwithme, and tell me what you're feeling.
open about
Greg has always been very open about his sexuality.
They were openly contemptuous of my suggestions.
We discussed our reservations about the contract quite openly.
People find it difficult to talk openly about death.

children.name: up front
children.definition: honest and willing to tell the truth, even if the truth is unpleasant: thẳng thắn
examples: He’s always up front and willing to admit his mistakes.
up front about
The company’s directors have been surprisingly up front about their financial problems.
be up front with sb
Karen is always very up front with her boyfriends.

children.name: straight
children.definition: honest and likely to tell people exactly what you think or what is happening, without trying to hide anything: thẳng thắn
examples: Tony Blair stated that he was ‘a pretty straight kind of guy’.
informalTellme straight, would you rather we didn't go tonight?
be straight with sb
I don’t care what you’ve done, Mike - just be straight with me.
straight answer
I’ve asked several people what happened, but no one will give me a straight answer.

children.name: candid
children.definition: honest about your opinions and feelings, even if other people disapprove of them: thật thà, thẳng thắn, bộc trực
examples: Lena is amusingly candid when she talks about the men in her life.
To becandidwithyou, I think you're making a dreadful mistake.
candid about
The management team has been very candid about the problems the company is now facing.
candid discussion/ conversation/ comment etc
She led a candid discussion about race relations in the city.
candidly[adv]
It can be useful to talk candidly about your feelings to someone.

children.name: tell the truth
children.definition: to be honest in what you say: nói thật
examples: He wouldn’t believe that I was telling the truth.
When you testify in court, you have to swear to tell the truth.
How do you know she's telling the truth?
tell sb the truth: nói thật với ai
Tell me the truth - does this dress make me look fat?

children.name: level with
children.definition: sb informal to be honest with sb, especially when they have asked you to give them the correct story, reason etc: nói thẳng, thẳng thắng với ai
examples: I promise I won’t get angry. Just level with me and tell me what happened.
I’m going to level with you - some of the other managers don’t think you’re ready for a promotion.

children.name: tell it like it is
children.definition: / tell sb straight to be honest and give sb all the facts about a situation, even if they are unpleasant: nói thẳng với ai
examples: I told her straight that she was wrong.
The people who report to me have to be willing to tell it like it is.

children.name: not mince (your) words
children.definition: to say what you think in a way that you know might offend other people: nói toẹt ra
examples: Helmut didn’t mince any words in his criticism of the department.

children.name: call a spade a spade
children.definition: informal to say exactly what you think about sb or sth, especially in a situation where other people would be more polite: có sao nói vậy
examples: Why not call a spade a spade and say that she’s incompetent, if that’s what you’re thinking.

children.name: pull no punches U
children.definition: pull no punches/ not pull any punches to speak honestly about sb or sth, especially when you are criticizing them, without thinking about their feelings: không ngại nói thẳng
examples: Rollins pulled no punches in his memoir, especially when writing about the political system.

children.name: tell the truth
children.definition: /ˌtel ðə ˈtruːθ/  to say what really happened or what the true situation is:
examples: nói sự thật
▪ Nobody believes me, even though I’m the only one telling the truth!
tell somebody the truth : nói cho ai biết sự thật
▪ You should have told him the truth.
▪ Just tell me the truth - did he give you the letter or not?

children.name: truthful
children.definition: /ˈtruːθfəl/  someone who is truthful says what is true and does not tell lies:
examples: thật thà ( không nói dối )
▪ Lucy’s normally an extremely truthful little girl.
truthful (with somebody) about : thật thà với ai về điều gì
▪ I’ve always been truthful with him about my other boyfriends.
truthfully[adverb]
▪ I want you to answer me truthfully.

children.name: to tell the truth
children.definition: /tə ˌtel ðə ˈtruːθ/  spoken say this when you want to be honest about something, even if it is something unpleasant that other people may not like:
examples: nói thật là
▪ To tell the truth I’ll be glad when the kids are back at school.
to tell you the truth : nói thật với bạn là
▪ I’m not really in the mood for going out. To tell you the truth, I’d rather stay in and watch TV.

children.name: stick to the facts U
children.definition: stick to the facts/ˌstɪk tə ðə ˈfækts/  to tell the truth about things that really happened and not invent things or give your opinions :
examples: bám vào sự thật, nói đúng sự thật
▪ Witnesses were asked to stick to the facts and leave aside all emotion and sentiment.
▪ ‘In my opinion, she was going to meet her lover.’ ‘Could you just stick to the facts, please.’

children.name: ways of saying that sth is really true
really
children.definition: /ˈrɪəli/  spoken:
examples: thật sự
▪ Is your cousin really a movie star?
▪ It’s all so long ago now, it’s difficult to believe that any of it really happened.
▪ ‘She’s leaving her husband, you know.’ ‘Really?’

children.name: honestly
children.definition: /ˈɒnɪstli, ˈɒnəstliǁˈɑːn-/ spokensay this toemphasizethat someone should believe what you are saying:
examples: nói thật, thật sự
▪ I was going to give you it back, honestly.
▪ I honestly don’t think we’ll be in court all day tomorrow.
▪ Honestly, it makes no difference to me where we have the wedding.
honestlyadverb thành thật
in a way that istruthful
_They have always dealt honestly and fairly with their customers.
_I can't honestly say what time I'll be home.
_I'll do it tomorrow, honestly (= I promise that I will do it) .

children.name: truly
children.definition: /ˈtruːli/  use this toemphasizethat you are sincere about what you aresayingand really mean it:
examples: thực sự
truly sorry/happy/surprised etc
▪ I’m truly sorry. I didn’t mean to upset you.
▪ For the first time in her life she felt truly happy.
truly believe/think etc
▪ If we truly believe we can win, then we have a very good chance at doing it.

children.name: when sb behaves in an honest way
honesty
children.definition: the quality of being honest : sự thành thật
examples: I appreciate your honesty.
Are you questioning my honesty?
Judy answered all the panel’s questions with honesty and courage.
As a newspaper reporter I am committed to honesty and accuracy.
I must tell youin allhonesty (= truthfully and hiding nothing) that there is little chance of the scheme being approved.

children.name: sincerity
children.definition: when you say or do things in a way that shows clearly that you honestly mean them : thật thà, chân thành, thẳng thắn
examples: ‘I’ll do anything I can to help,’ she said with sincerity.
Nothing about his behavior leads me to doubt his sincerity.
The priest was a man of deep sincerity.

children.name: openness
children.definition: when you are honest, friendly and happy to tell people the truth about yourself, especially about things that other people might be embarrassed to talk about: sự cởi mở
examples: Intimacy in a relationship requires openness.
The public expects complete openness from the President about his health.
If these discussions are to succeed, we'll need openness from/on both sides.

children.name: candor
children.definition: candour /  when you are honest about your opinions and feelings, even if other people disapprove of them: thẳng tính
examples: Winik writes with great candor, which has won her a wide following.
After so many lies from politicians, Dunbar’s candour is refreshing.
"We really don't know what to do about it, " she said with surprising candour.

children.name: integrity
children.definition: the quality of being honest and having strong moral principles that you refuse to change : tính thật thà
examples: Councilman Hughey’s integrity is unquestioned.
No one doubted that the president was a man of the highest integrity.
man/ woman of integrity
She is a woman of integrity who has never abandoned her principles for the sake of making money.

children.name: after all
children.definition: used to add information that shows that what you have just said is true :xét cho cùng
examples: I do like her - after all, she is my sister.
